page.lettertext:
fol.349r
25 October To my L. Trea
s
May it please your good L. With your l
re
s of
e 7 and 8
of this moneth w
c
were delivered unto me
e 18, I receaved
one fr
o
her
M
tie
to
e
g
na
l States
, w
c
I
p
sented unto them at their
next assemblie, and solicited her demaunde, for
e sending of their
shipping to
e coast of
Britaine
. Their answear therunto I have
sent heereinclosed, tending all to this effect,
t
they have taken
those affaires as much to hearte as was possible:
t
all
e last
s
o
mer, they expected very carefully her Hig
es
resolu
o
n, up
o
their
offers in
t
behalf, w
c
they had signified unto me, and I reported to
your L. in my l
re
s of
e 21 of Aprill and 16 of July:
t
as then
they had
e meanes to
fourme as muche as they had offered: but
understanding nothing fr
o
her M
tie
have imploied those meanes
in other exploites, and shall possiblely be able, to obtene of
e
Provinces
any further c
o
tribu
o
n, till
e spring of
e yeare.
And besides they must be forced, for w
a
t of victuals and
others
visions, to revoke those other shippes, w
c
they have
at this p
nt
on
e coast of Britaine. This day
M
r
Buzenval
receaved l
re
s fr
o
e
King,
to make a motion to
e States
like to
t
of her M
tie
. I have acquainted him at large w
t
their
answear unto me, to
p
pare him therby to meete w
t
their ob-
jections in
posing his maters. He is willed by
e King
to declare unto th
e
,
t
there hath passed a C
o
tract betweene
him and certaine inhabitants of
Gasconie
and Guien and the
towne of
Rochel
, who have lately undertak
e
up
o
certaine
couven
a
ts, to maintaine 20 shippes very thorowly furnished
for defense of those coastes, to w
c
e States are re
q
red to joine
some further strength. I will certify your L. w
at
answear
shall be made, though I see no likelihood of a better, th
e
is
giv
e
to her M
tie
. As touching
e often staies of
e c
o
panies of foote, w
c
I doubte are yet detened by a c
o
trary
winde, I hope your L. is certified fr
o
e
Gouvernour
of
Flushing
and
S
r
Francis Vere
: who remaine in
e place, where
e companies
are, and, as I am informed, have receaved in charge some
other addresses, then have bin by any imparted to me. For
I
test unto your L. of her Hig
es
resolu
o
n, to have
e souldiers
to be shipped for
Jersey;
and not for
Caen,
I have onely heard
fol.349v
a litle by a privat frinds l
re
, and
t
very barely and im
fectly:
t
I know not in particular, what hath bin written about it,
nor what order there is tak
e
for
e acc
o
plishing thereof.
Which I signify so unto you, to
e ende your L. may consider,
t
by reas
o
of my being so farre fr
o
Flushing, and my w
a
t of
intelligence of suche altera
o
ns, I cane neither give advise in
e assisting of others, nor advertise your L. of those affaires of
e footebandes. It hath also enfor c ed me to delay the dispatche
of
e c
o
pany of horse, a greate deale longer then I would.
For having signified by a l
re
of
e 21 of Sep
t
for what occasi
o
s
of
e c
o
trey I did not urge
S
r
Nicholas Parker
, to embarke himself
p
nt
ly, and having had ther
u
to no answear untill now, nor no
directi
o
for changing
e place of
e Rendevous, it caused me
to doubt
t
e horsebande should be staied, and therfore knewe
not how to deale, w
t
out some warr
a
t in other sort: w
c
though
your L. hath sent, yet
e place of
e Rendevous is not m
e
tioned
unto me. That at first I gave eare to
Count
Maurices
intercessi
o
, in suffering
e horseband to c
o
tinue heere
in service, your L. will vouchsafe to make
e best of that
ceeding in your dealing w
t
her Hig
es
. For it was at
e inst
a
ce
of
e Co
u
t and all
e c
o
trey, for a very short time, and for
a special exploite. There were also such impedim
e
ts,
as your L. did approve: for w
c
e c
o
pany of necessitie should
be forced for a time to remaine in
e c
o
trey. Withall I
understood then p
nt
ly after, and now I doe finde it to be true
by ex
ience,
t
howsoever I had resolved;
e Co
u
t and
e States
w
c
were in
e army, were determined fully to stay
e Company
in
e campe. I hope
t
your L. hath allway
s
ceaved,
t
I was never in my actions a pleaser of thi
s
people, but where I thought it might redounde to
e ser
vice
of her M
tie
. For
e further
a
ce wherof it c
a
not be o[therwise]
chos
e
, but according to
e occasions, I must vary very [much]
fr
o
e strigthnes of my charge: w
c
yet I never did hit[herto]
but it turned in
e end to
e adv
a
tage of her purpose.
And where her Hig
es
is displeased for
e numbers of strang
ers
intertened in
e horsbandes, if it should be understood, to [come]
fol.350r
by my default, I would humbly beseeche you to call to re-
membrance, what I pleaded for my self in my l
re
to your L.
e 10 of Ja
n
last: up
o
an other like c
o
plaint of
e weakenes
of
e c
o
panies s
e
t into
Normandie.
For
e causes th
e
alleaged
I hope I shall not neede to be p
nt
ly troublesome. I was
never yet willed, since I came to this place, to take any kinde
of charge of looking to
e Musters. I was never made acquain
ted by
e way of any l
re
or copie of any l
re
, w
t
e orders sette
downe by my
LL.
of
e Councel: and yet they have bin renued
at sundry times, and at every time sent to every Englishe
Gouvernor. If I had bin c
o
manded to deale in those affaires
up
o
receate of s
o
instructi
o
, I would not have failed to have
done my duty thorowly. Howbeit I doe not understande
but
t
e Commissaries certificats are c
o
tinually s
e
t home, and
e state of every bande made knowe unto th
e
,
t
are appointed
ex
p
ssly to examine those maters, and have allwaies there
e meanes, both to shewe th
e
to your L. and to seeke redresse
for all abuses. And namely for
e bande of S
r
Nicholas Parker,
although it hath passed
e rest, in n
u
ber, strength, and
furniture, yet notice hath bin give to
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
by
M
r
Allen
e C
o
missary, as well by his musterrolles and bookes
of warr
a
ts, as otherwise,
t
is troupe was full of strangers.
And being told by
e C
o
missarie
t
by her M
ts
orders he could
be allowed but onely six, he answeared for himself,
t
he had
licence for more fr
o
my LL. of
e Councell. His
c
o
pany is now in garris
o
at
Duisbourgh:
but I have earne-
stly moved both
e g
na
l States and
e
Councell,
to give their
pasport and licence for his coming to
Bergh
e
,
where
S
r
John
Poley
is in garris
o
, and where according to
e order
p
scribed
by her M
tie
he may supplie his deficients out of
e troupe of S
r
John Poley, and make is others c
o
muta
o
ns both of horses and
horsm
e
, and also p
nt
ly embarke his soldiers for Britaine.
I made my moti
o
first to
e Councel of Estate, as to whom
it belonged by vertue of
e C
o
tract, to give direction in suche
affaires. But because it c
o
cerned
e removing of a c
o
pany
out of this c
o
trey, they refused to take order, w
t
out
e [leave]
fol.351r
and assent of
e g
na
l States: to wh
o
they s
e
t for advise.
The states, for
t
her M
tie
had not writt
e
unto th
e
about it, re-
quired me to exhibit an Act of my hand, and to notify thereby
t
it was her Hig
es
pleasure: w
c
I
fourmed immediatly.
I should but trouble your L. w
t
a needeles rehearsal of all the
meetings and debates and sendings to and fro,
t
were used in this
mater. But
e States in c
o
clusion did not onely make
deniall of graunting their Pasport for removal of
e Company,
but enjoined the Councel and Co
u
t Maurice (who hath c
o
monly
usurped, to give his patents in such cases) not to deale in
e mater. I urged earnestly to know
e reas
o
of
t
ceeding,
c
o
sidering my demaund was but onely for a c
o
pany, and they
had suffered already 16 others to passe, and likewise those
e last yeare
t
were s
e
t for Normandy, w
t
out such open
oppositi
o
. I doubted
e issue would be this,
t
her M
tie
would
be moved to revoke all
e rest. Notw
t
standing all my
urging I could gette no other reas
o
, but
t
they could not
mitte it. But wh
e
I m
e
tioned
e revoking of
e rest
of
e horsm
e
, Co
u
t Maurice repleied, That he could rather
wishe it were p
nt
ly done, th
e
to tary till
e spring, and th
e
to have them on
e soddaine to be called away, when
e c
o
trey
should relie up
o
e benefit of their service. Wherto I an-
sweared againe,
t
there had never no suche course bin taken
by her M
tie
. They had allways had warning suffici
e
t before,
and if then after they would in hand w
t
some enterpris a freshe,
e faulte was in themselves, if they were not assisted. And
as for
e horsbande of S
r
Nicholas Parker, if they would not
mitte him to passe by good order, I would endevour what
I could to effect it otherwise: and if any inc
o
venience
ensued up
o
it, it rested in them to satisfy
e c
o
trey.
Moreover I intreated
e Councel both th
e
and before at
several times, to
hibit their captaines by some publick
edict, to receave any Englishe soldiours,
t
should goe fro[m]
those captaines, w
c
were going for Britaine. Where [unto]
they made answear, That they could not c
o
straine any
souldiour of this c
o
trey, to follow his captaine in a forr[aine]
fol.351r
c
o
trey: and as for those of
e Englishe nati
o
,
t
should runne
fr
o
their Captaines and put themselves in service heere in
e pay of
e c
o
trey, they used a kind of c
u
ning, in c
o
terfaiting
of Dutche names, and could be hardly discovered by their
C
o
missaries in
e musters. And besides by placcarts already
published it was forbidd
e
to any Dutche captaine to inter-
tene any stranger of what nation soever. Up
o
these kind of answears, I c
a
not yet resolve, in what sort
I should
ceede, to draw away
e horsband. I doubt very
muche it will not
p
vaile, to stoppe their weekely lendinges.
Of force they must have meanes for themselves and their
horses. And if they live up
o
e towne, where they lie now
in garris
o
, no doubt their horses will be stayed till restitu
o
n
shall be made. Againe if
e state will seeme to uphold
e Dutche souldier in refusing to goe for Britaine, I c
a
not
ceave by any en
q
rie,
t
both
e c
o
panies together of S
r
Nicholas
Parker and S
r
John Poley, are able to furnishe a full c
o
pany
of Englishe horsm
e
. And although S
r
Nicholas Parkers be
e strongest of
e fower c
o
panies, and was very c
o
plete
e
beginning of this s
o
mer: yet now I heare
t
his numbers
are very muche diminished: and for
e other three, they are
said to be farre weaker th
e
S
r
Nicholas Parkers: so as some
of them, I doubt, have scarcely half their n
u
ber.
The very best way,
t
I c
a
thinke up
o
p
nt
ly, to
cure
e c
o
pany a passage, is to cause
e Officer of
e T
re
r, to
sende those shippes,
t
shall be hired by him for transporta
o
n
of th
e
, to come up to
e Waert by
Utrecht
, and to cause
S
r
Nicholas Parker to come thither w
t
his horses. W
c
yet is a
mater full of difficultie and d
a
ger, by reas
o
of
e officers
and boores of
e c
o
trey, w
c
are wont for
e most to stoppe
e passage of any c
o
pany,
t
cometh w
t
out a passeport: and
also oft
e
times, for a very small misdemeanour of any c
o
m
o
soldier, to putte themselves in armes, and to invade
e whole
troupe. The report going heere,
t
divers
boates of this c
o
trey and some messengers w
t
l
re
s directed for
England have lately miscaried, because I am uncertaine
fol.351v
whether any of those l
re
s
t
I have writt
e
to your L. have
bin lost by such accid
e
ts, I have sent
e copie heere of one
above
e rest, w
c
I writte
e 10 of this moneth, and to my
understanding is most material. I am
lastely to become an humble suitour to your L.
t
it would
stand w
t
your honorable favour to put her M
tie
in rem
e
brance
of my long being heere, for fower years together: and
t
in respect of her Hig
es
busines, I could never be better
spared, nor had never greater cause, in respect of mine
owne: w
c
is wholy confused, and groweth worse every
day, by meanes of mine absence. Of divers hopes
t
I have
had, through
e answears of your L. to my former peti-
tions,
e last was differred to
e ende of this s
o
mer: w
c
the
sooner you shall be pleased to effect w
t
her Hig
es
e more
I shall be bound to acknowledge your goodnes, being otherwise
most bound for many singular occasions.
And so I take
my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage. Oc
t
1592.
